title: Fortress Don Meij defies global Domino's logic
text:
Domino’s held its annual strategy day for institutional investors in Brisbane on Thursday, which chief executive Don Meij devoted to rejigging (again) his eternal growth story.

Meij would have the market believe his two foremost strategic neuralgia – delivery aggregators and territory saturation – are truly growth levers in disguise! Deliveroo and Uber Eats are “a search engine for food”, “no different to Google” and “no different to the social media platforms”. And store splits – where new stores open inside the customer catchments of existing stores, cannibalising their sales – have been rebranded “fortressing”. What does Don call cancer? Cell count prosperity?!

Only on Tuesday, Don’s master franchisor, the New York Stock Exchange-listed Domino’s Pizza (DPZ), downgraded both its international same store sales growth (SSSg) outlook (30 per cent of which are royalties from Don) and its own domestic sales guidance, acknowledging “the comparable sales drag as we plan to further ramp up our fortressing program”.

Ironically, while Don’s is the only Domino’s globally to allege store splits are a positive, it’s also the only to exclude new stores (and existing stores whose territories have been cannibalised by those new stores) from its reported SSSg.

DPZ does not.

And DPZ’s next largest licensee (25 per cent of its international sales), the London Stock Exchange-listed Domino’s (DOM), even breaks out the negative impact of its store splits for the market. In the six months to June 30, SSSg in the UK was 3.9 per cent, but only 1.8 per cent when including the impact of splits. That’s 210 basis points of Fortress Downside.
